title: Longest ever non-stop commercial flight to Australia lands after 19 hours
text:
Qantas CEO Alan Joyce (C-R) shaking hands with Qantas pilot, Captain Sean Golding (C-L) with the crew in front of a Qantas Boeing 787 Dreamliner plane after arriving at Sydney international airport (Picture: Getty/AFP)

A commercial plane has spent a record 19 hours and 16 minutes in the air.

The Qantas aircraft flew non-stop from New York to Sydney over the weekend.

The good news is the test flight seems to have gone well so you may be able to catch the service soon.

The Boeing 787 Dreamliner, which touched down on Sunday morning, was used to carry out a series of tests to assess the effects of ultra-long-haul flights on crew fatigue and passenger jetlag.

Qantas pilots captain Sean Golding (L) and first officer Jeremy Sutherland in the cockpit of a Qantas Boeing 787 Dreamliner plane in New York (Picture/AFP/Getty)

Passengers and crew exercising on the plane (Picture: AFP/Getty)

Australian airline Qantas said tests ranged from monitoring pilot brain waves, melatonin levels and alertness, to exercise classes for passengers, including a rendition of the Macarena dance.

A total of 49 people were on board, to minimise weight and give the necessary fuel range.

To reduce jetlag, the crew kept the lights on for the first six hours during nighttime, to match the time of day at the destination.

They also served lunch first instead of dinner to keep up the illusion of being in a different time zone.

Captain Sean Golding, who led the four pilots, said: ‘Overall, we’re really happy with how the flight went and it’s great to have some of the data we need to help assess turning this into a regular service.’

The plane lands at Sydney international airport (Picture: AFP/Getty)

The flight was part of Project Sunrise – Qantas’s goal to operate regular, non-stop commercial flights from Australia’s east coast cities of Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne to London and New York.

The airline is planning two more research flights as part of the project evaluations – London to Sydney in November and another from New York to Sydney in December.

Qantas Group chief executive Alan Joyce added: ‘We know ultra-long-haul flights pose some extra challenges but that’s been true every time technology has allowed us to fly farther.

‘The research we’re doing should give us better strategies for improving comfort and well-being along the way.’

description: The Qantas aircraft flew non-stop from New York to Sydney over the weekend.
